plants.feeding: Fertilise with an organic water soluble fertiliser every two weeks from spring to fall, when the plant is actively growing in a container. Feeding is not generally needed for plants grown in beds in semi-tropical climates.
plants.notes: Lemon verbena is the most "lemony" of all lemon foliage herbs. Locate it where leaves can be conveniently picked, crushed and sniffed.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as desired. Smelling lemon verbena is a special delight of summer best captured in teas. Dry perfect leaves in small bunches, and store them in airtight containers.  This is a fragrance herb to delight your sense of smell and can be used in flower arrangements.
plants.companions: Use this 3-foot (90 cm) tall herb as a movable accent in your summer herb garden.
plants.troubleshooting: Repot plants in spring, gradually moving to slightly larger pots. In summer, sink the pot into the ground to protect it from overheating and drying out on hot days.

plants.soil: Rich soil that retains moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun in cool climates; partial shade where summers are very hot.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Lovage will reach its mature size in about three years.  One plant is usually sufficient, but its a good idea to start a new plant every few years.  At maturity, lovage will need a 90 cm (3ft) square space. It is a very large herb. Because of its 1.5 meter (5ft) height, lovage is best located at the edge or rear of the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Lovage is a hardy perennial that survives winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Topdress the soil around the dormant plant with rich compost each winter.
plants.notes: Tender young growth has the best flavour. In summer, consider pruning plants back to force them to push out a flush of new leaves.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen for their celery flavor. Freeze extra leaves by covering chopped lovage leaves with water in ice cube trays.
plants.troubleshooting: Remove flowers should lovage produce too many unwanted seedlings. Or, gather lovage seeds and use them in cooking as a substitute for celery seeds.

plants.soil: Rich soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Morning sun with partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased plants, set out in spring. Many selected cultivars are resistant to powdery mildew, a common problem with this species.  30 cm (12in) each way is a good spacing for an initial planting of 3 plants. Monarda is a slight spreader, but not invasive like mint. Over time, a happy plant will form a mount 120 cm (4ft) high and wide.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial which can survive temperatures to -30C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Topdress the dormant plants with good compost in winter.
plants.notes: Pastel flower colours look especially cooling in partial shade. Leaves are excellent for tea.
plants.harvesting: Harvest stems to dry for tea in early summer, before the plants bloom. The plants will regrow after cutting, then bloom.
plants.companions: Monarda thrives with other sun loving perennial flowers and looks lovely with cosmos.Bbeloved of the bees it is also known as Bee Balm and is excellent for attracting pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Moving clumps every few years may help limit problems with powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, because stevia seeds are very reluctant to sprout. Plants are grown from rooted cuttings taken from greenhouse-grown plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Stevia is a tender perennial grown as a vegetatively propagated annual. Parent plants brought through winter indoors provide rootable stems in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed. If needed, a water soluble organic fertiliser can be provided in midsummer to invigorate plants.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in midsummer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Stevia is an upright plant which goes with mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Stevia thrives in warm weather, and may grow slowly under very cool conditions.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot near the back or edge of a garden bed, because tarragon is a lanky plant.
plants.sowPlant: Set out a purchased plant in late spring. The best strain, called French tarragon, is propagated exclusively by rooting cuttings. At maturity, tarragon will need a 90 cm (3ft) square space.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, tarragon can survive temperatures to --30C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Tarragon covers itself with yellow-orange blossoms in late summer.
plants.harvesting: Gather stem tips as you need them in the kitchen. Tarragon can be dried, or you can use fresh tarragon to make flavored vinegars.
plants.companions: Often planted with thyme and other low, mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Tarragon has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out seedlings two to four weeks before your last frost. After two years, valerian will grow into a 18" (45 cm) wide clump.
plants.frostTolerant: Extremely cold hardy, even in harsh winter climates. Plants die back to the ground in winter and re-emerge in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Valerian produces extremely fragrant flowers in early summer. Gather them for use as cut flowers to keep valerian from reseeding and becoming invasive.
plants.harvesting: Dig roots in fall or early spring and dry outdoors, because they release an unpleasant smell as they dry. Store in airtight container. Dried valerian roots are used to make a bedtime tea that promotes sleep. They are also much loved by cats and dogs.
plants.companions: Often planted with low, mound-forming herbs and flowers. Valerian can stand 1.5 m (5ft) tall when it is in full bloom.
plants.troubleshooting: Control valerian's spread by cutting back flowering stems before they can shed seeds in your garden.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased bulblets or corms, set out 10 to 6 weeks before your first autumn frost, or in early autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Multiplying onions and other perennial strains are typically hardy to -15C (-26F) when given a protective winter mulch.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting a new bed.
plants.notes: Most perennial onions grow vigorously in early spring and die back in midsummer. These interesting yet variable plants resemble shallots more than other onions.
plants.harvesting: Harvest bulblets from topsetting onions and use them as pearl onions in the kitchen. When plants die back, cured roots often yield a small shallot. In spring or autumn, you can cut off small divisions for use as spring onions.
plants.companions: Often grouped with other perennials.
plants.troubleshooting: In autumn move perennial onions to a fresh location to avoid problems with onion root maggots, which are attracted by decomposing onion tissues.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Easiest to sow onion sets (tiny bulbs) which are planted direct into the soil from autumn/fall onwards. Can also be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late winter before planting out mid-late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required, though overwintered sets can be given a liquid feed in spring.
plants.notes: Japanese variety onion sets can be used to give an early harvest. Onion sets are also the better choice for heavier or wetter soils.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Easiest to sow onion sets (tiny bulbs) which are planted direct into the soil from autumn onwards. Can also be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late winter before planting out mid-late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required, though overwintered sets can be given a liquid feed in spring.
plants.notes: Japanese variety onion sets can be used to give an early harvest. Onion sets are also the better choice for heavier or wetter soils.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in late winter to plant out in early spring. Or sow direct into ground from mid spring onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from early spring to early summer.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late winter to spring and transplant to final positions when ready.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Wait until a few light frosts have passed to harvest, because cool weather enhances the sweet flavour of cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to move to final positions in autumn to be over-wintered and ready for spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf colour and type. Most early-maturing cabbage varieties produce smallish heads.
plants.harvesting: Harvest early plants or leave to mature to a firm 'heart' until early summer.  Small secondary heads often grow from the base of early cabbage plants after the primary head is cut.
plants.troubleshooting: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.

plants.notes: Other perennial plants. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
Cover crop, usually planted in fall after others have been harvested.  You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow buckwheat from late spring to late summer, whenever a bed will be unused for more than three weeks.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. Thin to 10 cm (4in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Buckwheat cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using buckwheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Limit reseeding by pulling up or turning under buckwheat just after it blooms, but before it develops mature seeds.
plants.harvesting: Buckwheat can be pulled up and composted or turned under any time. It will return the most organic matter when taken down 5 to 6 weeks after seeding.
plants.companions: Mixes well with upright flowers, and makes an attractive backdrop for herbs. A small bed of buckwheat in bloom will attract numerous beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Buckwheat has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun in very warm locations only.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in summer, when the soil is warm. Crowder peas will not germinate in cold soil.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Crowder peas are semi-tropical plants that crave warm growing conditions.
plants.feeding: When using crowder peas to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Crowder peas are a good nitrogen-fixing summer cover crop for warm climates, where the vegetable seasons are sharply divided by a period of hot weather.
plants.harvesting: Pull up or turn under plants any time after they are about 4 weeks old, but before they develop pods.
plants.companions: Other heat-tolerant summer-blooming annuals.
plants.troubleshooting: Rarely bothered by pests or diseases when grown in warm weather.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow fenugreek from late spring to late summer, whenever a bed will be unused for more than eight weeks.  Direct seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. Thin to 15 cm (6in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Fenugreek cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using fenugreek to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: On warm days, fenugreek often emits a fragrance similar to that of maple syrup. It also can be grown as a medicinal herb.
plants.harvesting: Mow plants before turning them under, or pull them up and compost them if you want to use the spot for planting right away.
plants.troubleshooting: Fenugreek rarely has problems with pests and diseases when grown in home gardens.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer to use mustard as a short-term autumn green manure. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2 in) deep. Thin to 15 cm (6in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Mustard is cool-season annual that can tolerate light frosts but not hard freezes.
plants.feeding: None generally needed, because mustard is customarily used as a late summer/autumn cover crop to take up nitrogen left in the soil by sweet corn or other vegetables.
plants.notes: You can gather individual leaves for cooking, which taste best after the first frost has passed. Mustard residue suppresses soil-borne nematodes, so it is an excellent green manure to grow before potatoes.
plants.harvesting: Chop down the green foliage with a hoe and turn it under just before hard freezes are expected. The mustard roots and foliage will rot during the winter months.
plants.companions: Mustard does an excellent job of suppressing weeds when grown in a solid mass.
plants.troubleshooting: Irrigation is often needed to get a good stand if autumn is dry.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun in very warm locations only.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds from late spring to early summer. Soya beans must have warm soil to germinate and grow.  Poke holes into a cultivated bed or row to plant soybean seeds about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. Thin to 15 cm (6in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Soya beans are a warm-season crop to grow in summer in hot climates.
plants.feeding: When using soya beans to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Soya bean green manures are used primarily to add nitrogen to poor soil.
plants.harvesting: Chop down or pull up plants just as they begin to flower. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.
plants.troubleshooting: Soya beans are very attractive to deer.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer so that plants can become established before cold weather comes. In cold climates, crimson clover can be planted in early spring instead of autumn. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: Established plantings made in early autumn can tolerate temperatures to -18 C (0F).
plants.feeding: When using crimson clover to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results. Using inoculated seed can also help to grow a vigorous stand.
plants.notes: Crimson clover is one of the most beautiful cover crops you can grow.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants just as the red tops begin to fade, but before the plants produce mature seeds. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. They can then be turned under or composted. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.
plants.companions: Often planted with hardy annual flowers including bachelor buttons and corn poppies.
plants.troubleshooting: Crimson clover plants become quite tough as they age, but they seldom regrow when cut off at the soil line.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow hairy vetch in late summer so the plants can become established before cold weather comes.   Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to - 29C (-20F) when well rooted in the garden.
plants.feeding: When using hairy vetch to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Hairy vetch stays small through winter and makes vigorous growth in spring. It is highly recommended as a green manure to grow before tomatoes.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants in spring, 3 weeks before the bed is needed for summer vegetables. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. The cut plants can be allowed to dry into a surface mulch.
plants.troubleshooting: Hairy vetch can become weedy if allowed to produce mature seeds.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer to grow as a green manure that forms its own mulch when it is winterkilled, or when using oats as a companion crop for slower-growing legumes. Oats also can be grown as a spring green manure to increase soil organic matter.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm (8in) apart when growing oats with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Oats are a cool-weather crop that can tolerate light frosts but is usually killed by temperatures below-15C (5F).
plants.feeding: None generally needed, especially when oats are grown with nitrogen-fixing green manures such as winter peas, winter beans or hairy vetch.
plants.notes: Oats are an ideal late summer green manure if your winters are cold enough to kill it; the dead residue forms its own winter mulch, which is usually well rotted by spring.
plants.harvesting: Young oats can be turned under anytime. In mild winter climates, oats should be mowed and tilled before seedheads appear in late spring.
plants.troubleshooting: Rotting oat foliage has herbicidal properties, in that it inhibits germination of weed seeds. Always wait 3 weeks before sowing seeds into soil where oats have been turned under.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer or early autumn as a green manure.  Make sure seed is well covered, because phacelia seeds need darkness to germinate.
plants.frostTolerant: Phacelia will survive mild frosts to overwinter and bloom in spring.
plants.feeding: None generally required.
plants.notes: Phacelia is a wonderful plant for attracting bees and other beneficial insects, particularly useful in early spring if it has overwintered as it is an early pollen source for bees coming out of hibernation.
plants.harvesting: For maximum benefit as a green manure dig in when quite small.  Otherwise leave plants to grow up to 1m (3 ft) tall as the flowers attract beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Although native to California in the US phacelia harbours damaging lygus bugs, so it is rarely grown there.

plants.soil: Any soil, including poorly drained sites.
plants.sowPlant: Walk over the planted site to firm the seeds into the ground, and then water to promote fast germination. Although customarily grown in autumn, annual rye can be used as a fast-growing green manure in all but the hottest summer months.   Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 1 inch (2 cm) apart and one-fourth inch (.5 cm) deep.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardiness varies with variety. Some strains are killed by temperatures around -23 C (-10F), while especially hardy varieties can tolerate more extreme cold.
plants.feeding: When using annual rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Mature annual rye plants can be difficult to dig out. Where annual rye is not killed by winter weather, mow down the plants and turn under the residue when the plants are young.
plants.harvesting: In a home garden, annual rye cover crops are easiest to manage if they are mowed every few weeks. The clippings make excellent mulch.
plants.companions: Annual rye forms a very thick stand, and is normally grown alone to choke out weeds and boost organic matter, especially in new gardening sites.
plants.troubleshooting: Annual rye has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in early autumn, though cereal rye will still germinate in mid autumn, after the soil has lost its warmth. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm (8in) apart when growing cereal rye with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Most varieties of cereal rye can survive temperatures to -29C (-20F) if the plants are well rooted before the ground freezes.
plants.feeding: When using cereal rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter and break up dense subsoil.  Can be sown later in the autumn than other green manures.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds. Or, gather the immature seed tops and dry them for arrangements, and then pull up the plants. They can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.companions: In spring, widely spaced rye plants can serve as trellises for garden peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Deer often nibble cereal rye in winter.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer or early autumn for an overwintered crop. Spring wheat can be planted while the soil is still cool.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm (8in) apart when growing wheat with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to - 23C (-10F) when well rooted in the garden. Grow varieties described as soft spring wheat in spring, but choose hard winter wheat for autumn.
plants.feeding: When using wheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter, break up dense subsoil and crowd out weeds. Makes a beautiful show in spring.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds. Or, gather the immature seed tops and dry them for arrangements, and then pull up the plants. They can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.troubleshooting: Deer often nibble wheat grown in winter.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Poke holes in prepared seedbed and plant seeds 5 cm (2in) deep. Winter field beans may be planted in late summer, or in very early spring.  In milder areas they can be planted quite late into autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: A cool-season annual, winter field beans can tolerate frost but are killed by temperatures below -12 to -9C (10-15F).
plants.feeding: When using winter field beans to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase soil nitrogen. Easier to turn under using hand tools compared to other green manures.  Small-seeded varieties are best for green manure use.
plants.harvesting: For maximum nitrogen gain, chop plants down and turn them under as soon as they begin to bloom.  You also can pull up the plants and compost them.
plants.troubleshooting: Winter field beans attract numerous beneficial insects. Do not grow them just before potatoes or other root crops, because field beans can host rootknot nematodes.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Poke holes in prepared seedbed and plant seeds 3 to 5 cm (1 to 2in) deep. Gaps between plants can be filled with an upright grain.
plants.frostTolerant: A cool-season annual, winter field peas (Austrian peas), can tolerate heavy frost but are killed by temperatures below -17 to -23C (0 to -10F).
plants.feeding: When using winter field peas to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase soil nitrogen. Highly recommended as a winter green manure to go before sweet corn because of its vigorous nitrogen-fixing activity in early spring. Very low weedy potential compared to other green manures.
plants.harvesting: For maximum nitrogen gain, chop plants down and turn them under as soon as they begin to bloom.  You also can pull up the plants and compost them.
plants.troubleshooting: Allow at least 3 weeks after turning under winter pea residue before direct-seeding vegetables, because the rotting vegetation can cause an increase in damping off of seedlings.

plants.soil: Average garden soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow alyssum from early spring to early summer, and in autumn where winters are mild. Alyssum grows fast and often stops blooming in hot weather.  Broadcast seeds into cultivated soil or containers about 2 inches (5cm) apart, and barely cover them with soil. When the seedlings have more than four leaves, thin to 6 inches (15 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Alyssum seedlings can tolerate light frost, but plants are often killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting. Encourage reblooming with a liquid feed.
plants.notes: Can reseed if allowed to do so, but extra seedlings are easy to lift and move or pull out.
plants.harvesting: Tired alyssum plants often melt down in hot, humid conditions. As annual flowers go, they are short-lived.
plants.companions: In white or pastel shades, alyssum in the perfect little flower to tuck into the corners of beds, or you can grow it beneath tall vegetables or among herbs. Alyssum is famous for attracting tiny wasps and other beneficial insects.

plants.soil: Any good garden soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow cornflowers from early to mid spring for early summer bloom. Also sow in fall in climates with mild winters. Plant seeds in soil or in containers about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young cornflower seedlings can tolerate freezing temperatures, so seeds can be planted in early spring, or in the autumn where winters are mild.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Rice-size cornflower seeds are much loved by goldfinches and other small seed-eating birds.
plants.harvesting: Cornflowers make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants in mid to late summer, when they no longer look attractive.
plants.companions: Cornflowers have an upright posture that helps them fit in tight spaces. Intersperse throughout the garden, as cornflower nectar is unusually sweet, and thus a preferred food source for many beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Cornflowers may be nibbled by rabbits, especially in early spring when other food is scarce.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow cosmos in early spring so the plants can become established before hot weather comes.  Cosmos also can be started indoors in containers and set out when the seedlings have at least five leaves, or purchased as bedding plants. Plant seeds in prepared soil about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 12 inches (30 cm) between very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frosts, but plants are killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Varieties vary greatly in height, colour and flower form. Choose dwarf varieties for tight spaces.  Sulphur cosmos (C. sulphureus) thrives in humid heat.
plants.harvesting: Cosmos make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants and compost them when blooms become few or freezing weather is expected.
plants.companions: Tall varieties can form a colourful hedge that attracts bees and other pollinators, and mix well with tall herbs like dill and fennel.
plants.troubleshooting: In some climates, cosmos planted in spring may not come into full bloom until days become short in early autumn.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow marigolds in late spring, or set them out as bedding plants. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 12 inches (30 cm) between very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: None.  Marigold cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: The 'Gem' marigolds (T. tenufolia) bear edible blossoms with a spicy, citrus flavor.
plants.harvesting: Marigolds make good short-stemmed cut flowers for small bouquets. Don't rush to pull up plants that stop blooming but look healthy, because they will probably come back into bloom.
plants.companions: Dwarf types make good edging plants that may deter rabbits. Some varieties are known for their ability to starve out rootknot nematodes when planted the year before and macerated and then ploughed into the soil where the chemicals that affect the nematodes are then released.
plants.troubleshooting: Marigolds have few problems with pests or diseases.  Tall varieties may need staking to keep them upright.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Soaking seeds in water overnight prior to planting may speed germination, but nasturtium seeds sprout best when the soil is warm. Poke seeds into the soil about 1 inch (3 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Nasturtiums may survive very light frosts, but they are easily damaged by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Nasturtium blossoms, leaves and immature green seed pods are edible.
plants.harvesting: Gather nasturtium blossoms in the morning, when they are plumped up with moisture. Snip away the base of each blossom, which may taste bitter.
plants.companions: Nasturtiums sprawl out over the ground, so they suppress weeds and shade the soil when grown near tall plants like sweet corn, tomatoes or sunflowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Nasturtium will often reseed itself in hospitable sites.

plants.soil: Any fertile soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow poached egg plant in early spring, while the soil is cool. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 4 inches (10 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young seedlings can tolerate light frost, but the plants are easily damaged by hard frosts.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Pull up old plants to limit reseeding. Where summers are hot, plants may expire after blooming heavily in spring.
plants.harvesting: The delicate flowers and fragrance of poached egg plant always bring cheer to the garden. Pull up and compost plants when they stop blooming heavily.
plants.companions: This low-growing plant spreads into a mat of green foliage covered with flowers. Grow along pathways or edges of beds, or near tall plants like sweet corn or tomatoes.
plants.troubleshooting: Poached egg plant has few problems with pests or diseases, but may fail when subjected to extreme humid heat.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Salvia needs warm soil to grow well, so wait until the last frost has passed to set out plants. Start seeds indoors in individual containers or set out purchased plants. Space plants 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Salvia cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Pinching off the first bloom will encourage plants to grow into lush bushes bearing numerous flower spikes.
plants.harvesting: Gather stems to use in cut arrangements. Snip off old flowers every few weeks to keep plants in bloom all summer.
plants.companions: Mixes well with upright flowers or herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Salvia has few problems with pests or diseases.  Newer named varieties are vigorous and very heavy blooming.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow sunflowers from late spring to early summer.  Poke seeds into the soil about 1 inch (3 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties. Extremely tall sunflowers or those that grow into multi-branched bushes may require 3 feet (1 meter) between plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Sunflower seedlings often escape damage from light frost, but sunflowers are warm-natured plants with no tolerance of freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Explore different sunflower varieties, which vary in size, colour, growth habit, and the culinary quality of the seeds.
plants.harvesting: Cut sunflower heads when some of the seeds inside the edges appear ripe and fall away when rubbed, or when birds start harvesting them for you. Store in a warm, dry place.
plants.companions: A rare "shelter" plant, sunflowers can be used to create shade for sun-stressed crops. Tall varieties can serve as trellises for transplanted runner beans seedlings (but not those grown from seed in the same area as sunflower seedlings are  negatively allelopathic to competitors.)
plants.troubleshooting: Sunflowers will twist around to face the south or west, seeking the most abundant source of sun, which may be away from your garden.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Plant zinnias in late spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.  Start seeds indoors in individual containers, set out purchased plants, or direct-sow into warm soil. Poke seeds into the soil about one-half inch (1 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties. Zinnia varieties that grow more than 24 inches (60) cm) tall require 18 inches (45 cm) between plants.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Zinnias cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  In midsummer, drench plants with a high-nitrogen liquid fertiliser to stimulate strong reblooming.
plants.notes: Frequent cutting of blossoms helps many varieties to rebloom constantly for many weeks. Butterflies prefer flat, single zinnia blossoms over "double" varieties that are packed with petals.
plants.harvesting: Gather zinnias for use in arrangements just as the petals open. The true flowers are the tiny yellow florets, which pump out nectar for butterflies.
plants.companions: Also grown with fennel and other upright herbs. Tall, single-flowered varieties attract butterflies.
plants.troubleshooting: Older zinnias often become infected with powdery mildew. Pull up and compost diseased plants. Many hybrids offer some resistance to powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in containers in late winter, and set out seedlings in spring. You can also work with purchased seedlings, or lift and move volunteer seedlings found in the garden. Set plants at least 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions. They are easily recognized by their lacy leaves.
plants.frostTolerant: Six-month-old, well rooted plants tolerate winter temperatures to --29C (-20F).  Most individual plants die in their second or third summer, after blooming heavily.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  When plants emerge after their first winter, mulch with rich compost or topdress with a balanced organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Frequent cutting of blossoms helps feverfew stay in bloom longer. Depending on climate, feverfew is a biennial or short-lived perennial.  When seeds are started early, it will bloom its first year.
plants.harvesting: To harvest for medicinal use, gather when the plants are in full flower but still holding an abundance of greenery. Medicinal preparations are made from a mixture of dried flowers and leaves.
plants.companions: Also grown with beds of other tea plants where insects are not wanted. Feverfew repels insects of all nature, so it is a good plant to grow near entryways.
plants.troubleshooting: Feverfew can reseed too well in hospitable spaces, so keep an eye on it for invasive tendencies.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in spring. Established plants can be dug and moved anytime as long as soil is kept packed around the roots. Start seeds indoors in individual containers, set out purchased plants, or direct-sow into warm soil.  Space plants 30cm (12 in) apart in all directions. Few gardeners need more than a few of these productive plants.
plants.frostTolerant: When established, this hardy perennial can tolerate winter temperatures to -29C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  Each spring, mulch around the plant with rich compost.
plants.notes: Pinch off blossom spikes to keep plants from reseeding in the garden, and to increase productivity. Young leaves that grow in cool weather have the mildest flavor.
plants.harvesting: Gather individual leaves as needed in the kitchen.
plants.troubleshooting: For top productivity, replace plants every few years.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow tatsoi in spring and again in late summer for harvest in autumn. Sow in double rows, with rows spaced 10 inches (25 cm) apart. Plant seeds 2 inches (5 cm) apart and barely cover them with soil. Gradually thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Tatsoi can tolerate light frost, but exposure to cold temperatures in spring can trigger early bolting. In autumn, exposure to light frost can improve tatsoi's flavor.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: This beautiful little mustard cousin often grows better in autumn than in spring.
plants.harvesting: Gather individual leaves, or pull whole plants for use in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Also grown with other greens found in oriental salad mixtures. In autumn, tatsoi looks beautiful with pansies and parsley.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles often chew small holes in tatsoi leaves in spring, but are less of a problem in the fall.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow bok choy in spring and again in late summer for harvest in autumn. Sow in double rows, with rows spaced 10 inches (25 cm) apart. Plant seeds 2 inches (5 cm) apart and barely cover them with soil. Gradually thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart. Miniature varieties can be grown 3 inches (8 cm) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Bok choy can tolerate light frost, but exposure to cold temperatures in spring can trigger early bolting. In autumn, exposure to light frost can improve bok choy's flavor.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Also spelled pac choi, this lovely little mustard cousin is fast and easy to grow.
plants.harvesting: Pull whole plants for use in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Often grown with lettuce, mustard, kale, escarole, tatsoi, mizuna and other greens found in oriental salad mixtures. Miniature varieties are available for square foot gardens and containers.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles often chew small holes in bok choy leaves in spring, but are less of a problem in the fall.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots in mid spring then plant out once all danger of frosts is past.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Keep moist by watering regularly. Pinch out the growing tip once the plant has made three leaves and do the same to side shoots as they appear.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit as soon as it feels slightly soft when the ends are pressed.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Sheltered sunny position or under cover.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in early spring. Transfer to bigger pots as required. If planting out then do so from mid spring when soil has warmed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed once the plant is a reasonable size.
plants.notes: Sometimes require supports.
plants.harvesting: Harvest peppers green when they have grown to a good size or wait for them to ripen to yellow or red if preferred. Chilli peppers will get hotter when left and can be dried out in the sun before storing.
plants.troubleshooting: Hot weather increases hot compounds in chillis, so those grown in cool climates may lack heat.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Cold tolerance varies widely with species.
plants.feeding: In early spring, mulch over root zone with 1 to 2 inches of good compost. Mulch with grass clippings or straw.
plants.notes: Obtain local expertise before choosing which fruits to grow.
plants.harvesting: Let experience be your teacher -- taste fruits often as they approach ripeness. Bumper crops can be frozen, dried, or made into jams and jellies.
plants.troubleshooting: In winter, use chicken wire (poultry netting) to protect young plants from rabbits, deer etc.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Benefits from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring, topped by a deep mulch of wood chips or sawdust year round.
plants.notes: Prune in winter to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. Most varieties need at  least one other pear tree in the neighbourhood to get good  pollination. Healthy pear trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Harvest pears before they fully ripen, and ripen under cool indoor temperatures.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Very cool or hot weather can affect ripening, and leaving fruits on the tree for too long can cause them to rot from the inside out. Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen.Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.  For a large spread, pears can be grown at 10m apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive clay or loam.
plants.position: Sunny spot, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young plum trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Feed with a mulch of high nitrogen fertiliser in spring. Keep plum trees mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Some varieties are self-fertile; otherwise at least one other plum flowering at the same time will be required for pollination. Prune in late winter, before buds begin to swell.  Healthy plum trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit feels soft when gently squeezed. As fruit ripens, some fruits will fall from the tree, and others can easily be shaken onto cloths spread on the ground.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Plums can be affected by silverleaf disease  prune in dry weather in summer to help avoid infection. In humid climates, plums often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality plums.

plants.soil: Fertile, moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.
plants.position: Sunny spot with excellent air circulation. You will need two trees for good fruit set with sweet cherries. Standard tart cherries are often self fertile, and make nice landscape trees.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young cherry trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Cherries benefit from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter and a feed with a balanced organic  fertiliser in spring
plants.notes: Many sweet cherries need to be grown with at least one other flowering at a similar time for pollination, but many tart  cherries are self-fertile. Prune in late winter to shape trees and removed damaged branches. Healthy cherry trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick cherries carefully so as not to damage the delicate fruit.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Use netting to prevent bird damage. In humid climates, cherries often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. However, because cherries ripen early, they have fewer disease problems compared to many other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Sheltered south or south-west facing wall or fence, or under glass in cooler climates. Elsewhere peaches need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young peach trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring, along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under peaches mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Peaches may need to be hand-pollinated when grown in sheltered spots. Prune peaches hard in late winter. Healthy peach trees will bear for fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick peaches when the colour has fully developed and the flesh gives slightly when squeezed. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping peach trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl. In humid climates, peaches often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality peaches.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Sheltered south or south-west facing wall or fence, or under glass in cooler climates. Elsewhere nectarines need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young nectarine  trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring , along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under nectarines mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Nectarines are self-fertile, but produce better when more than one tree is grown.  Prune nectarines hard in winter. Healthy nectarine trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when the colour has fully developed and the flesh feels soft near the stalk. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keep plant dry under cover to avoid peach leaf curl. In humid climates, nectarines often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality nectarines.

plants.soil: Deep, moisture-retentive but well-drained, slightly alkaline soil.
plants.position: Best grown against a sheltered south-facing wall in the cooler climates. Elsewhere apricots need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young apricot trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes. Cold damage to apricot blossoms is a major limiting factor in where they can be successfully grown.
plants.feeding: Feed with balanced organic  fertiliser in early spring. Keep the area beneath apricots mulched with wood chips, straw, or another mulch that helps maintain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or mid to late summer in cooler climates. Elsewhere prune apricots in late winter. Healthy apricot trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit is soft and can be pulled easily from the tree. Ripe apricots fall to the ground.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Dieback and oozing resin can often be remedied by improving growing conditions. Mulching, watering, feeding, weeding and hard pruning can all help. In humid climates, apricots often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality apricots.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.position: Best grown trained against a sunny, sheltered south or west facing wall, or under cover in cooler climates. In warmer climates, kiwis thrive in full sun provided their roots receive midday shade.
plants.sowPlant: Add plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. Plant next to a strong trellis for support.
plants.frostTolerant: Young shoots are vulnerable to frost damage in spring; may require protection.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in late winter, and apply a balanced organic  fertiliser in early spring, just as new growth emerges.
plants.notes: Most kiwi varieties require both male and female plants for successful pollination. One male plant can pollinate up to eight nearby females. Hardy kiwis produce smaller fruits, but are usually self fertile. Healthy kiwi vines trees will bear for ten years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick before the first frosts and then ripen indoors if the fruit is not completely ripe.
plants.companions: Kiwi vines are so vigorous that they dominate their space and require a sturdy trellis.
plants.troubleshooting: Will only crop if they are planted in a warm enough position, and may suffer from dieback in cold winters.

plants.soil: Deep, fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Stake trees for the first 3-4 years. Healthy medlar trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Can harvest in autumn before the fruits are fully ripe or else leave until they ripen if there is no danger of frost. Fruit must first be bletted before eating raw.  To do this, leave them in a cool place until they turn dark red-brown and become soft.
plants.troubleshooting: Medlars are naturally astringent, like persimmons.

plants.soil: Moist, boggy, acid soil. Ideally, a mixture of sand and acidic organic matter.
plants.position: Grow in prepared beds that can be kept very moist or flooded. Bushes can be grown along the ponds edge in  sun or partial shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in a water-retentive spot by a pond or stream, above the water line, or in a bog-like bed in a low area.
plants.frostTolerant: Plant in a water-retentive spot by a pond or stream, above the water line, or in a bog-like bed in a low area.
plants.feeding: Mulch with acidic  compost to keep soil constantly moist. For the first three years after planting, top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser in spring.
plants.notes: Water only with rainwater. Cranberries will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Begin harvesting three years after planting. Harvest when fruits are red and ripe, but before they have been damaged by hard freezes.
plants.companions: Rhododendrons and azaleas.
plants.troubleshooting: Grows best in acid soil with a pH of 4.0 to 5.5.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.position: Full sun to partial shade. Like currants and gooseberries, jostaberries make good bushes for garden boundaries. Unlike gooseberries, they have no thorns.
plants.sowPlant: Plant from late autumn to mid spring while dormant. Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter into the planting hole.
plants.frostTolerant: Developed in Germany, jostaberries are extremely cold hardy.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the root zone mulched to retain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Each winter, remove the oldest canes from established plants, and clip of damaged or drooping branches. Healthy jostaberries will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when fruits turn blue-black and are firm. Freezes well.
plants.companions: Jostaberries grow best when planted together in small groups.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a sturdy frame of wires against a wall or on posts. Plant with the crown 8cm (3") below soil level and apply a thick mulch. Cut the stems to a strong bud
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: After harvesting, cut 2 year old branches to ground level. Healthy loganberries will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when ripe. Loganberries do not ripen all at once, and should be picked weekly through the second half of summer.
plants.companions: It is best to keep the area around a mound of loganberries mowed to make picking easier.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage. Plant a thornless variety to take the pain out of harvesting.

plants.soil: Rich, well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter added.
plants.position: Grow in full sun up a pole support system or on a strong trellis against a long fence or wall. Hops are sensitive to day length, and produce best between 35 and 55 degree latitudes.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in hills in spring after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.
plants.frostTolerant: Hops are hardy perennials that require a period of winter chilling and a growing season of at least 120 days.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Hops need support and plenty of room to sprawl. They will quickly run to the top of a 20-foot vertical trellis. Some root trimming may be required to stop the rhizomes spreading too far. Hops will bear for several years before they should be replaced by younger, more vigorous vines.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when cones feel papery and dry, and leave a yellow powder on your fingers when touched. Dry in a warm spot away from sunlight.
plants.companions: Clover or other green manures are usually grown between rows of trellised hops.
plants.troubleshooting: Hops may develop mildew if they have inadequate air circulation. Prune vines to improve airflow.

plants.soil: Rich, light soil with plenty of organic matter added.
plants.sowPlant: Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes. Cold damage to spring blossoms is a major limiting factor in where almonds can be successfully grown.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with  a generous mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Almonds are best hand-pollinated when only one or two plants are grown. Healthy almond trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Knock nuts down when they start to drop, then peel and dry them.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping almond trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl and rotting fruits.

plants.soil: Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil.
plants.position: Sheltered spot in full sun or partial shade. Can be grown as a hedge.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, healthy hazel trees will bear twenty years or more.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Self-fertile but pollination is improved by growing in groups with two or more cultivars present. Begins to bear after five years. Healthy hazel trees will bear twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the husks begin to turn yellow in early autumn.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: The nuts are much-loved by squirrels, birds and rodents.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but flowers can be damaged by late frosts.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Healthy walnut trees will bear for many decades.
plants.harvesting: Knock down nuts when ripe, remove the peel and dry. If pickling, harvest while it is still possible to pierce the nuts with a skewer.
plants.companions: Can restrict growth in other plants nearby, because many plants (including tomatoes) are sensitive to juglone, a substance present in walnut roots, leaves and wood.  Walnuts should be grown in an orchard of their own, far from the vegetable garden.

plants.soil: Light, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.   For a large spread, chestnuts can be grown at 20m apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Some varieties are not self-fertile, so more than one will need to be planted for successful pollination. Healthy sweet chestnut trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: When ripe nuts fall from the trees, remove the husks (wearing gloves) and dry.
plants.companions: These are large, spreading trees that cast dense shade. The area beneath sweet chestnuts makes a good summer sitting area.
plants.troubleshooting: Squirrels, rodents and birds will steal the nuts.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7C (45F).
plants.feeding: In spring, summer and autumn feed with a high nitrogen organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company, so companion plants have to be planted a little way away.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators and to avoid most pests. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7C (45F).
plants.feeding: In spring, summer and autumn feed with a high nitrogen organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company, so companion plants have to be planted a little way away.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators and to avoid most pests. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7C (45F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company, so companion plants have to be planted a little way away.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators  and to avoid most pests.  Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7C (45F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company, so companion plants have to be planted a little way away.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators  and to avoid most pests.  Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7C (45F).
plants.feeding: In spring, summer and autumn feed with a high nitrogen fertiliser. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company,so companion plants have to be planted a little way away.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators and to avoid most pests. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7C (45F).
plants.feeding: In spring, summer and autumn feed with a high nitrogen fertiliser. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company,so companion plants have to be planted a little way away.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators and to avoid most pests. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.  Figs grow well in large containers.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a south-facing wall or under cover. Figs grown as pillars or espaliered plants can be planted closer - 45cm (18in) apart, and gradually thinned to the best specimens.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in containers or in a hole lined with solid material that the roots cannot penetrate to encourage fruiting.
plants.frostTolerant: Reasonably tolerant, but the tips of branches carrying fruit can be damaged in cold weather so protect branches with horticultural fleece in winter in cooler regions. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often re-grow.
plants.feeding: Top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser each spring, and mulch with well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves but otherwise do not store well.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mite when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds, squirrels and wasps. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.  Figs grow well in large containers.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a south-facing wall or under cover. Figs grown as pillars or espaliered plants can be planted closer - 45cm (18in) apart, and gradually thinned to the best specimens.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in containers or in a hole lined with solid material that the roots cannot penetrate to encourage fruiting.
plants.frostTolerant: Reasonably tolerant, but the tips of branches carrying fruit can be damaged in cold weather so protect branches with horticultural fleece in winter in cooler regions. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often re-grow.
plants.feeding: Top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser each spring, and mulch with well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves but otherwise do not store well.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mite when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds, squirrels and wasps. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Well-drained alkaline soil.
plants.position: Sunny, sheltered spot. In cooler climates grow under cover to ensure fruiting. Requires lots of heat to ripen fruits. Pomegranates are self-fertile, so single plants fruit well.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants grown from rooted cuttings in late winter or early spring. Named cultivars produce better than pomegranates grown from seeds.
plants.frostTolerant: Pomegranates tolerate cold to -12C (10F)
plants.feeding: Fertilise with a balanced organic fertiliser in November and March.
plants.notes: Prune outdoor plants in spring, and indoor plants in early winter. Remove dead, broken or crossing branches as well as any suckers that have appeared at the base of the plants.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when ripe. The fruit stores well in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Pomegranates grow into tall, dense shrubs that shade out other plants,so companion plants have to be planted a little way away.
plants.troubleshooting: Pomegranates often do not start bearing until they are five years old.

plants.soil: Warm, fertile, well-drained soil with a slightly acidic pH.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in late winter or early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but most grow and crop more reliably under cover in cooler climates.
